The synchronized swimming events were first introduced in the Summer Olympics in 1984 but gained significant attention and popularity in the 1988 Summer Olympics held in Seoul, South Korea. The significance of synchronized swimming events lies in the performance of athletes who combine gymnastics, dance, and swimming into synchronized routines, which require precise timing, coordination, and skill.

At the 1988 Olympics, the United States and Canada dominated the synchronized swimming events, winning gold medals in both the duet and team competitions. The United States team was the first to perform to music, which added a new level of creativity and complexity to the sport. The event marked a turning point in the sport's history, leading to the inclusion of duet and team events in all subsequent Olympic games. Since then, synchronized swimming has become a popular Olympic sport, with countries such as Russia, Spain, and Japan emerging as dominant forces.
